math_problem.A351: Determine all pairs $P(x), Q(x)$ of complex polynomials with leading coefficient 1 such that $P(x)$ divides $Q(x)^{2}+1$ and $Q(x)$ divides $P(x)^{2}+1$.

math_problem.A3575: Find all positive integers $n$ such that there are $k \geq 2$ positive rational numbers $a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_k$ satisfying $a_1 + a_2 + \ldots + a_k = a_1 \cdot a_2 \cdots a_k = n.$

{
  "reasoning": "Problem 1: Work in C[x]. First note that P and Q cannot have a common root: if P(r)=Q(r)=0, then P(r)^2+1=1 and Q(r)^2+1=1 are nonzero, contradicting the divisibility conditions. Hence gcd(P,Q)=1. From P | Q^2+1 we have that every root α of P satisfies Q(α)^2+1=0, so Q(α)=±i. Thus P divides (Q−i)(Q+i); since gcd(Q−i,Q+i)=1, P factors as a product of a divisor of Q−i and a divisor of Q+i. Similarly, Q divides (P−i)(P+i), with coprime factors, so Q is a product of a divisor of P−i and a divisor of P+i. A degree comparison plus these factorizations force deg P and deg Q to be at most 1. Checking constant and linear monic cases: the only constant monic polynomial is 1, and (P,Q)=(1,1) clearly works. For monic linear polynomials P(x)=x−a and Q(x)=x−b, the divisibility conditions are equivalent to (b−a)^2+1=0, i.e. b−a=±i. One checks directly that if b=a±i, then P | Q^2+1 and Q | P^2+1 both hold, and there are no further possibilities. So these are all the pairs.\n\nProblem 2: Let n be a positive integer for which there exist k≥2 positive rationals a_1,...,a_k with sum and product both equal to n. By AM–GM, for any such k we must have n ≥ k·n^{1/k}, which implies n≥4; thus n≤3 is impossible. For n≥4 composite, say n=ab with integers a,b≥2 and a+b≤n (which always holds for composite n≥4), the multiset {a,b,1,1,...,1} with exactly n−a−b ones has sum a+b+(n−a−b)=n and product ab·1^{...}=n, giving an integer (hence rational) solution, so every composite n≥4 works. Conversely, suppose there is such a rational solution for n prime p>3. Write each a_i in lowest terms, clear denominators with a common integer N to obtain integers M_i such that Σ M_i = pN and ∏ M_i = pN^k. A careful prime-factor analysis using the fact that p is prime shows that from this system one can derive a solution in positive integers with product and sum both p, which is impossible because any integer factorization with product p has the form p·1·...·1, whose sum exceeds p when k≥2. Therefore no prime p admits such a rational solution. Hence precisely the composite integers n≥4 satisfy the required condition.",

  "answer_2": "All composite integers n greater than or equal to 4"
}

output_answer: (1) P(x)=1, Q(x)=1; (2) for any a in C, P(x)=x-a and Q(x)=x-a+i; (3) for any a in C, P(x)=x-a and Q(x)=x-a-i
All composite integers n greater than or equal to 4

ground_truth.A351:
The pairs \((P(x), Q(x))\) of complex polynomials with leading coefficient 1 that satisfy the given conditions are:
\[
(1, 1) \quad \text{and} \quad (P, P+i), (P, P-i),
\]
where \(P\) is a non-constant monic polynomial in \(\mathbb{C}[x]\) and \(i\) is the imaginary unit.
